formula: Conjecture. Let a(1)=a(2)=1 and for n > 2 let k = floor(sqrt(n+1))-1 and d=n-k(k+2). Then, if (d is 0, 1, or 2) OR (d=0 mod 2), a(n)=2k+1; otherwise a(n)=2k+3. This has been verified for n <= 15000. Thus the asymptotic behavior appears to be a(n) ~ floor(sqrt(n+1)). - _John W. Layman_, May 21 2002

By induction, a(1)=a(2)=1, a(3)=a(4)=a(5)=3 and for k >= 3 we obtain the following formulas for the 2k-1 consecutive values from a(k^2-2k+2) up to a(k^2+1): a(k^2+1) = a(k^2) = 2k-1, if 1 <= i <= 2k-3 then a(k^2-i) = 2k-2-(-1)^i, hence asymptotically a(n) ~ 2*sqrt(n). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Jul 28 2002

a(n) = 2*floor(n^(1/2)) + r where r is in {-1,1}. More precisely, let g(n) = round(sqrt(n)) - floor(sqrt(n+1)-1/sqrt(n+1)); then for n >= 1 we get: a(2*n) = 2*floor(sqrt(2*n)) - 2*g(ceiling(n/2)) + 1 and something similar for a(2*n+1). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Mar 06 2009
a(n) = 2*floor(n^(1/2)) - (-1)^(n + ceiling(n^(1/2))) for n > 0. - Branko Curgus, Feb 10 2011
